results.title: How fair is the jury system?
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Ministry of Education, George Cass and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: An audience of students questions a prominent barrister on the fairness of the jury system. The program considers such issues as choosing a jury, eligibility of jurors and alternatives or reforms of the jury sustem.

results.title: How electricity is produced
results.creator_credit: Pat Dowling Pictures, Pat Dowling and Thomas Stanton
results.brief_description: Explains the three ways in which electricity is produced. Depicts Faraday discovering the principle of an induced current, and demonstrates with a small magneto-generator the principle of current electricity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Pat Dowling Pictures, Pat Dowling and Thomas Stanton

results.title: How effective is your reading?
results.brief_description: This film is designed to help students and adults improve their reading skills. Demonstrates methods of faster reading and better understanding, emphasising at the same time the need for practice. Illustrates a number of specific reading skills, including how to read in larger thought groups, to skim, to read when in search of information, and how to read rapidly but at the same time comprehend fully.

results.title: How does it strike you?
results.brief_description: Shows a group of postprimary students role playing an industrial strike and the process of negotiation. Highlights the processes involved in an industrial strike.

results.title: How does it feel?
results.creator_credit: Pictures That Move, Arts Council of Great Britain and Mick Csaky
results.brief_description: Covers various areas of neurophysiology, creativity and bio energetic therapy, with a commentary about getting back in touch with our senses. Gives a number of insights about human nature, twentieth century living conditions and creativity. Based on the book by Frances Hudson.

results.title: How does a rainbow feel?
results.creator_credit: WH Productions, Stanley S Madeja and Donald Wise
results.brief_description: Shows the variety of aesthetic educational qualities in the environment - sounds, shapes, patterns, colours and textures. Children are seen exploring and discovering such areas as body movement, shapes, points of view, characterisation and dramatic plot. In the final minutes of the film, a class of primary school children create a dramatic plot about a young boy with a violin named the “Rainbow King”. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: How does a computer work?
results.brief_description: An animated guide through the complexities of the central processor function of the computer, showing how it controls the input and output of information, how it calculates and how it makes logical decisions. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: How does a candle burn?
results.brief_description: Demonstrates how the properties of candle wax change as the wax is transformed from a solid to a gaseous state and explores the nature and shape of the flame and the function of the wick.

results.title: How do you drive?
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Walford Hewitson and Roger Blais
results.brief_description: Released for general use as a public service by the Royal Canadian Air Force, this film demonstrates driving skills as taught at a National Defence Driving School. It follows the course of instruction of a new driver, and shows basic rules for handling a car under a variety of conditions, from turning a corner to halting a skid on ice.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, Walford Hewitson and Roger Blais
